1558127.title: 29 East 4th Street - Lafayette Street
1558127.folder: 29 East 4th Street - Lafayette Street, Manhattan, NY

720801f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720801f-a.text:
Lafayette Street, west side, north from a point above E. 4th
Street, to Astor Place (right), showing prominently the row
of distinctive structures known ss ''Colonnade Row''. Note
the ''Churchman'' in the north building. At the right margin
appears a glimpse of the Wannamaker (formerly A. T. Stewart)
Department Store building.
1911
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

720794f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720794f-a.text:
416 Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th Street and Astor
Place, showing the Diocesan House.
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

1558128.title: 29 East 4th Street - Lafayette Street
1558128.folder: 29 East 4th Street - Lafayette Street, Manhattan, NY

720798f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720798f-a.text:
(1)
428-434 and 436-44O Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th
Street and Astor Place. No. 428-434 is known as the ''Colonnade
Buildings.'' It is a part of the row of houses which was known as
Colonnade Row,vhere John Jacob Astor and other prominent merchants
lived in the 1870's. The building shown in this view is the northern
half of the Row and its northernmost section was for many years occupied
by the Churchman, the leading paper of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
It was then known as 47 Lafayette Place and was the centre of New Yorks
intellectual supremacy. For a number of years the building has been
occupied by the Conte Restaurant and is still there to date (1937).
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing an exclusive view of the Colonnade Buildings.
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
No. 432 Lafavette Street was the home of dulia Gardner, bride of
President Tyler.

720803f.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720803f.text:
Lafayette Street (Elm Street), north from but not including East 4th,
to and including East 8th Streets (where it terminates), show:ing construction
work in progress on the Interborough Rapid Transit Co. (I.R.T.) Subway.
In the background is shown the Germania Theatre, adjoining the N.W. corner
of Fourth Ave. IIt was later razed and on its site was erected (between 1902
and 1905) the 14-story main building of the John Wanamaker Department Store.
On the right are visible the lower floors of the Astor Library, now (1937)
the home of the Hebrew Immigration Aid Society ('Hias'').
April 1, 1901.
Board of Transportation Photograph.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
William B. Parsons Collection.

720802f.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720802f.text:
Lafayette Street,West Side,between E.4th Street and
Astor Place,showing the ''Colonnade Row,'' where John Jacob Astor
and other prominent Americans have resided.
About 189S
Langwill,

720800f-a.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720800f-a.text:
Lafayette Street,at the North West corner of East dth Strect. This
place lcter became the printing house of the C.J.O'Brien Company.
About I920
M.B.R.

720797f.title: Manhattan: Lafayette Street - 4th Street (East)
720797f.text:
428-34 Lafayette Street, west side, between East 4th Street
and Astor Place, showing the distinctive row of houses
known as the ''Colonnade''. This was formerly called ''La Crange
Terrace'', in honor of General Lafayette's home. They were
erected in 1827 snd for a time were the home of Washington
Irving and John Jacob Astor. The Churchman, the leading
paper of the Protestant Episcopal Church was published here
at the time when this was the center of New Yorks intellectual
supremacy, at what was then No. 47 Lafayette 'lace. For a
number of years this building has been occupied by the Conte
Restaurant.
1938-9
Works Progress Authority  reg tPG ES
Federal Writers Project
CREDIR LINE IMTERATIVE
